docs.lead_paragraph: Most women experience morning sickness early in their pregnancies. But it does not necessarily strike only in the morning, nor does it always end after the first trimester. I, for one, felt sick at various times of the day, especially when I smelled something off-putting, like garbage or meat being cooked, and every day on the subway on my way home, until I realized that it helped to eat something before I left the office.

headline.main: Reasons, and Remedies, for Morning Sickness

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses morning sickness during pregnancy which affects 70 to 80 percent of pregnant women; new report by American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issues guidelines for 2 percent of pregnancies that involve severe symptoms called hyperemesis gravidarum; possible reasons for nausea and vomiting discussed; taking multivitamins, eating smaller meals and avoiding certain foods are suggested for pregnant women experiencing such symptoms; hospitalization for hyperemesis gravidarum discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Most women experience morning sickness early in their pregnancies. But it does not necessarily strike only in the morning, nor does it always end after the first trimester.    I, for one, felt sick at various times of the day, especially when I...

keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about the American anti-abortion movement's "incremental" approach to legislation; they then evaluate key decisions, regulations, and legislation from the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision, Roe v. Wade, to the present, from both sides of the abortion debate.

byline.original: By ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and YASMIN CHIN EISENHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of abortion rights supporters rallied Sunday in the nation's capital, protesting the policies of the Bush administration and its conservative allies and vowing to fight back in the November election. The huge crowd marched slowly past the White House, chanting and waving signs like ''My Body Is Not Public Property!'' and ''It's Your Choice, Not Theirs!,'' then filled the Mall, turning it into a sea of women, men and children for the first large-scale abortion rights demonstration here in 12 years.

headline.main: Abortion Rights Marchers Vow To Fight Another Bush Term

docs.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of abortion rights supporters rally in Washington, DC, protesting policies of Bush administration and its conservative allies and vowing to fight back in Nov election; organizers of first large-scale abortion rights demonstration in capital in 12 years claim more than million people participated; speaker after speaker accuses Pres Bush and his allies in Congress of trying to impose ideological agenda on abortion and family planning programs, both at home and abroad; many leading Democrats and backers of Sen John Kerry attend march and address crowds; Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton notes that no such march was necessary during her husband's administration, when government respected rights of women; Bush administration officials claim Bush's policies are solidly in mainstream of American public opinion; he opposes abortion except in cases of rape or incest, or to save life of woman, but says country is not ready for outright ban on abortion; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of abortion rights supporters rallied Sunday in the nation's capital, protesting the policies of the Bush administration and its conservative allies and vowing to fight back in the November election.    The huge crowd marched...

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a recent Saturday morning at Yoga Haven in Tuckahoe, 15 pregnant women settled onto rubber mats and greeted one another with questions about how they were feeling and when their babies were due. Then the instructor, Reyna Gonzalez, guided them through a prenatal yoga routine. ''Breathe into the baby,'' Ms. Gonzalez coached. ''Note how the baby responds.''

headline.main: The Quest for the Perfect Birth

docs.abstract: Health care professionals in Westchester County, NY, say county's higher than average education and income levels make women there more aware of range of choices and trends in giving birth; note that obstetrics practices and hospitals are under pressure to keep up; more flexible and comfortable maternity units cited; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Kalpana Krishnamurthy rallies supporters here this weekend at a march for abortion rights, the first such national gathering in 12 years, she will be doing so as director of the Third Wave Foundation, a nationwide feminist group. But Ms. Krishnamurthy's perspective on the issue is shaped by far more than domestic debate. Her parents immigrated to the United States from India, where most of her large extended family still lives and where although abortion is legal, the right to it is intertwined with continuing battles over other women's issues, including domestic violence and economic opportunity.

headline.main: For Abortion Rights Cause, a New Diversity

docs.abstract: Abortion rights advocates are preparing for April 25 march in Washington, DC, first such national gathering in 12 years; veterans of movement say they have been striving to address decline in support among women under age 30; young first-generation Americans and recent immigrants, many of whom maintain connections to countries where reproductive rights are part of still-burgeoning struggle over women's issues, are bringing new energy and broader perspectives to cause (M)
